qas.question: What frequency are antennas normally designed to be?
What can be added to f0 to create a standing wave pattern?
What multiple is essential for wavelengths?
How are waves which are used in the ways discussed controlled?

context: The standing wave forms with this desired pattern at the design frequency, <a0_0>f0<a0_0/>, and antennas are normally designed to be this size. However, feeding that element with <a1_0>3f0<a1_0/> (whose wavelength is 1⁄3 that of f0) will also lead to a standing wave pattern. Thus, an antenna element is also resonant when its length is 3⁄4 of a wavelength. This is true for all odd multiples of <a2_0>1⁄4<a2_0/> wavelength. This allows some flexibility of design in terms of antenna lengths and feed points. Antennas used in such a fashion are known to be <a3_0>harmonically<a3_0/> operated.
